member.name: N:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation
member.summary: Provides access to generic presentation layer functionality, such as the drag-and-drop framework, color schemes, and interactive surface device tilt values.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.GiveFeedbackEventArgs
member.summary: Represents event arguments for an attached event that is identified by the field.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.GiveFeedbackEventArgs.InvokeEventHandler(System.Delegate,System.Object)
member.summary: Provides the correct type casting used to call the event handler.
member.param: The target to call the handler for.
The generic handler to call in a type-specific way.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.GiveFeedbackEventArgs.Cursor
member.summary: Gets the object for the drag operation.
member.returns: Returns a object that contains information about the element that is being dragged.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.QueryTargetEventArgs
member.summary: Represents event arguments for an attached event that is identified by the field.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.QueryTargetEventArgs.InvokeEventHandler(System.Delegate,System.Object)
member.summary: Provides the correct type casting used to call the event handler.
member.param: The target to call the handler for.
The generic handler to call in a type-specific way.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.QueryTargetEventArgs.Cursor
member.summary: Gets the object for the drag operation.
member.returns: Returns a object that contains information about the element that is being dragged.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.QueryTargetEventArgs.ProposedTarget
member.summary: Gets or sets the proposed target element for the drop operation.
member.returns: Returns a object that represents the proposed target element for the drop operation.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.QueryTargetEventArgs.UseDefault
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to use the default hit-test result as the target.
member.returns: The value is true if the element identified by the default hit-test result should be used as the target; otherwise, it is false.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.SurfaceColors
member.summary: Provides access to the current palette of colors that are used to style Microsoft Surface controls in your application. Application developers can use those same colors to style additional elements in their applications. Alternatively, application developers can overwrite the Surface colors to affect any element in their applications that uses those colors.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.SurfaceColors.SetDefaultApplicationPalette(Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.SurfacePalette)
member.summary: Sets the values of the run-time object to the values in the specified palette, resulting in a change in the colors of your application.
member.param: An instance of the class, or an instance of one of the derived classes defined in the namespace.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.SurfaceDragDrop.BeginDragDrop(System.Windows.FrameworkElement,System.Windows.FrameworkElement,System.Windows.FrameworkElement,System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Windows.Input.InputDevice},System.Windows.DragDropEffects)
member.summary: Begins the drag-and-drop operation.
member.param: The data that is attached to the cursor.
The drag source of the cursor.
The visual content of the cursor. If the or property of cursorVisual is not explicitly set, the and properties of draggedElement are used as and for cursorVisual.
The allowed drag-and-drop effects of the operation.
The input devices that start dragging the cursor. The devices can be enumerable of or objects.
The element that is dragged from the drag source. The element's position and orientation are used as the cursor's initial position and orientation.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Tilt
member.summary: Specifies the physical tilt of the interactive surface.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Tilt.Horizontal
member.summary: The interactive surface is tilted no more than 20 degrees from the horizontal axis. The tilt angle is between 340 and 20 degrees.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Tilt.Tilted
member.summary: The interactive surface is tilted between 20 degrees from the horizontal axis and 20 degrees from the vertical axis. The tilt angle is between 20 and 70 degrees, or between 110 and 340 degrees.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Tilt.Unknown
member.summary: Tilt data is unavailable because the interactive surface hardware does not report tilt values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Tilt.Vertical
member.summary: The interactive surface is tilted no more than 20 degrees from the vertical axis. The tilt angle is between 70 and 110 degrees.

member.name: N:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Automation.Peers
member.summary: Defines a set of types that derive from the base class and that correspond to Microsoft Surface controls. Each class exposes the corresponding controls to user interface (UI) automation, enabling assistive technology products such as screen readers to provide information about the UI to end users and to manipulate the UI by means other than standard input. For more information, see UI Automation Overviewhttp://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=210311.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Controls.TagRemovedBehavior
member.summary: Defines the action to take for a object when its contact is removed from a object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Controls.TagRemovedBehavior.Disappear
member.summary: When the tag is removed, the visualization disappears immediately. By default, the object lifetime persists for 500 milliseconds after the tag is removed. (You can change this behavior by setting the property.) If the tag is added again within that interval (500 milliseconds), the visualization reappears at the new location, and the event occurs. If the tag is not added again, at the end of the interval, the visualization is removed from the object and the event occurs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Controls.TagRemovedBehavior.Fade
member.summary: When the tag is removed, the visualization gradually fades. The default fade duration is 1,500 milliseconds. (You can change this duration by setting the property.) If the tag is added again within that interval (1,500 milliseconds), the visualization reappears at the new location, and the event occurs. If the tag is not added again, at the end of the interval, the visualization is removed from the object and the event occurs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Controls.TagRemovedBehavior.Persist
member.summary: When the tag is removed, the visualization remains. If a user puts the same tag on the visualizer again, a new visualization is created. The default time-out period is 500 milliseconds after the tag is lost. (You can change this interval by setting the property.) If the tag is added again within the time-out period, the existing visualization is moved to the new tag location (similar to the behavior) instead of creating a new visualization.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Controls.TagRemovedBehavior.Wait
member.summary: When the tag is removed, the visualization remains until the tag is added again. When the tag is added again, the visualization moves to the new tag location. By default, the visualization remains indefinitely after the tag is lost. If you set the property to a finite value, the following behavior occurs: If the tag is added again within the specified interval, the visualization reappears at the new location, and the event occurs. If the tag is not added again, at the end of the interval, the visualization is removed from the object and the event occurs.

member.returns: The value is true if the interactive surface hardware can report that the display surface is tilted; otherwise, it is false.

member.returns: The value is true if reporting touch bounds is supported; otherwise, it is false.

member.summary: Gets whether the orientation of a touch point can be reported by the interactive surface hardware.
member.returns: The value is true if the orientation (direction) of a touch point can be detected; otherwise, it is false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Input.InteractiveSurfaceDevice.LogicalDpiY

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Input.InteractiveSurfaceDevice.MaximumTouchesSupported
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of simultaneous touches supported by the interactive surface hardware.
member.returns: Returns an value representing the maximum number of simultaneous touch devices that can be detected.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Input.InteractiveSurfaceDevice.PhysicalScaleTransform
member.summary: Gets the scale transformation to convert from device-independent pixels to inches.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Input.InteractiveSurfaceDevice.Tilt
member.summary: Gets a description of the physical tilt of the interactive surface device.
member.returns: Returns one of the enumeration values:Horizontal By default, within 20 degrees of the horizontal axis (0 degree angle).Vertical By default, within 20 degrees of the vertical axis.Tilted Any other value between Horizontal and Vertical.Unknown The tilt angle cannot be determined by the interactive surface hardware.The interactive surface device is considered to be if the tilt angle is within 20 degrees of the vertical (90 degree) axis, and if the tilt angle is within 20 degrees of the horizontal (0 degrees) axis. Any other tilt angle corresponds to . The Surface administrator can change that threshold from 20 degrees to some other value by using the Surface Configuration Editor. For more information, see the Surface Administration Guide.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Input.InteractiveSurfaceDevice.TiltAngle
member.summary: Gets the angle of the physical tilt of the interactive surface device.
member.returns: Returns a value representing the angle of tilt, in degrees. The interactive surface device is 0 degrees when the display is horizontal and facing up. The value returned is between -180 degrees and 180 degrees. If the interactive surface device is unable to report a tilt angle, Surface assumes a tilt angle of 90 degrees.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Input.InteractiveSurfaceDevice.WorkingArea
member.summary: Gets the working area of the interactive surface device in device-independent units.

member.name: N:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Palettes
member.summary: Provides classes that expose the palettes associated with the four Microsoft Surface color schemes. For more information, see Surface Colors and Palettes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Surface.Presentation.Palettes.DarkHighContrastSurfacePalette
member.summary: Provides access to the palette of colors that corresponds to the "DarkHighContrast" color scheme. This color scheme provides maximum visibility for users with low vision, in a dimly-lit environment.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
